Specific Details: Two meetings were held by Tetrarch Capital representatives Tom Sheridan and Ray Gilmore with Emer Higgins TD and Councillor Charlie O'Connor of South Dublin County Council on 22 February 2020 and 3 March 2020 respectively. A draft masterplan of the lands of Tetrarch's affiliate, Cape Wrath Hotel Limited, which adjoin and surround Citywest Hotel, was presented and discussed at each meeting.
DPOs Lobbied: Emer Higgins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Charlie O'Connor|Councillor|South Dublin County Council
Subject Matter: Two meetings were held by Tetrarch Capital representatives Tom Sheridan and Ray Gilmore with Emer Higgins TD and Councillor Charlie O'Connor of South Dublin County Council on 22 February 2020 and 3 March 2020 respectively. A draft masterplan of the lands of Tetrarch's affiliate, Cape Wrath Hotel Limited, which adjoin and surround Citywest Hotel, was presented and discussed at each meeting.
Intended Results: Tetrarch sought to make both DPOs aware of the draft masterplan presented at the meetings. Tetrarch proposes the rezoning of some of the amenity lands at Citywest Hotel to allow for their residential development. The draft masterplan envisages that at least 30% of the rezoned lands will be applied to affordable housing provision (in addition to the 10% reserved for Part V housing) and the delivery of very significant public amenity, education, sports and recreational facilities on the lands.
Lobbying Activities: The two meetings with the two DPOs were specifically about Tetrarch's draft masterplan for lands at Citywest Hotel.|Meeting|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tom Sheridan and Ray Gilmore of Tetrarch are the persons responsible for carrying out the lobbying referred to here.

Specific Details: Clarity on claiming for health expenses for gluten free foods via Revenue
DPOs Lobbied: Emer Higgins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Fergus O'Dowd|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Clarity on claiming for health expenses for gluten free foods via Revenue
Intended Results: Recognition by Revenue Staff of Coeliac Society Food list of gluten free foods, that once accompanied by a receipt any foods on this list can be reclaimed by a PAYE coeliac taxpayer.
Lobbying Activities: Deputies Emer Higgins and Fergus O'Dowd have been supporting us in this endeavour since early 2023 and into 2024|Email|6-10

Specific Details: School Meals Programme
DPOs Lobbied: Fergus O'Dowd|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Emer Higgins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: School Meals Programme
Intended Results: End the current discriminate against coeliac and gluten intolerant children with the roll out of the School Meals Programme in Sept 2023. Immediate action to make it compulsory that schools participating in the Programme cater to the needs of coeliac children where there is a demand for it. The Government has a duty to ensure that all children are treated equally and fairly, and that no child is left behind or excluded from the benefits of the Programme.::Coeliac Society is ready to support the DEASP and you with this information tool and to discuss solutions to ensure that all children can enjoy their school meals without fear or stigma.
Lobbying Activities: Meeting held with Deputies Emer Higgins and Fergus O'Down on 31st Jan 2024 to discuss this issue and how it might be rectified. It was decided to write to SafeFood directly as it was they who designed the guidelines for the provision of the School Meals Programme. SafeFood have been helpful and engaged as as result with the Society on this matter.|Meeting|1

Specific Details: Launching a National Screening Programme for Coeliac Disease
DPOs Lobbied: Fergus O'Dowd|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Emer Higgins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Launching a National Screening Programme for Coeliac Disease
Intended Results: Implementing a National Screening Programme for Coeliac Disease in 1-17 year olds in Ireland would enhance early detection, crucial for preventing complications like malnutrition. It would identify asymptomatic cases, raise awareness, provide valuable epidemiological data, and lead to economic benefits by reducing healthcare costs associated with undiagnosed cases. It would improve care and support for affected individuals, contributing to better health outcomes and societal well-being.
Lobbying Activities: This was raised at the meeting with Deputies Emer Higgins & Fergus O'Dowd on 31st Jan 2024.|Meeting|1

Specific Details: Correspondence with Minister Higgins regarding the Proposed Minimum Annual Remuneration Thresholds HCA to express concerns and frustrations that the Dept of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (DETE)had made decisions that will directly impact the nursing home sector without consultation or engagement again.
DPOs Lobbied: Emer Higgins|Minister of State|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Subject Matter: Correspondence with Minister Higgins regarding the Proposed Minimum Annual Remuneration Thresholds HCA to express concerns and frustrations that the Dept of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (DETE)had made decisions that will directly impact the nursing home sector without consultation or engagement again.
Intended Results: To express to Minister Higgins NHI's frustration that the proposed decision regarding MAR was made without the necessary consultation with our sector as per express commitment and agreement with your Department. No consultation with the DETE. When Minister Richmond agreed to defer the commencement in January of 2024, the DETE committed to consulting with our sector. NHI requested meeting with immediate engagement with the Minister on this very important issue for the sector.

Specific Details: To highlight the need to address the inconsistencies of current tobacco price lists displayed in retail outlets in relation to differing size, font, artwork and the selective nature of the products listed.
DPOs Lobbied: Emer Higgins|Minister of State|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Treasa Kelly|Special Advisor|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Subject Matter: To highlight the need to address the inconsistencies of current tobacco price lists displayed in retail outlets in relation to differing size, font, artwork and the selective nature of the products listed.
Intended Results: Legislation change to ensure that tobacco price lists displayed in retail outlets are standardised in terms of artwork, font and size, thereby removing ambiguity and the potential for abuse or exploitation of the tobacco price list.
